headline.main: Nepal Curbs Rights After Maoist Attacks

lead_paragraph: After attacks by Maoist rebels that peaked this morning, Nepal's constitutional monarch, King Gyanendra, declared a state of emergency tonight, suspending most civil liberties and authorizing the 50,000-man army to join the police in battling the five-year old insurgency. A palace communiqué, issued at the government's request, followed a six-hour clash between rebels and government forces this morning in an eastern district of Nepal. The fighting in recent days, the deadliest since the insurgency began, left more than 200 people dead, mostly rebels, the state radio reported.
abstract: Nepal's constitutional monarch, King Gyanendra, declares state of emergency following attacks by Maoist rebels; suspends most civil liberties and authorizes 50,000-man army to join police in battling five-year-old insurgency; recent events signal collapse of four-month-old cease-fire that brought three rounds of negotiations between government and Maoists that had raised hopes for peaceful resolution of conflict; rebels seek abolition of monarchy and establishment of Communist system in poverty-stricken country; photo; map (M)
